children.value: is Polish and hence must contain a perfect subset, contradiction.
Show that a Bernstein set is not Lebesgue measurable.

The existence of arbitrary choice functions appears to be a rather strong assumption. It has consequences that seem paradoxical in the sense that they conflict with basic intuitions we have about objects and they behavior with respect to size or other characteristics. Arguably the most famous example is the
, which uses the Axiom of Choice to partition a ball in

children.html: R3\Real^3R3

children.value: into finitely many pieces, and then, using rigid transformations (i.e.\ rotations and translations), to assemble them into two balls of the original size.

On the other hand, the Axiom of Choice implies or is even equivalent to many principles that are applied throughout many areas of mathematics, such as the existence of bases of vector spaces, Zorn’s Lemma, Tychonoff’s Theorem on the compactness of product spaces, the Hahn-Banach Theorem, or the Prime Ideal Theorem.
For some applications, however, a weaker form of the Axiom of Choice is sufficient.

children.html: X\mathcal{X}X

children.value: of non-empty sets has a choice-function.

children.value: showed that DC is no longer sufficient to prove the existence of non-regular sets in the above sense. He constructed (though under a large cardinal assumption) a model of ZF+DC in which every set of real numbers is Lebesgue measurable, has the Baire property, and has the perfect subset property.

Solovay:1970a.label: Solovay:1970a
Solovay:1970a.html: Solovay, R. (1970). A model of set-theory in which every set of reals is Lebesgue measurable. The Annals of Mathematics.
